title: Why are there so many Oreo Flavors? 1
author: Jack Beatty

pages.content: Why are there so many Oreo Flavors? Oreo cookies are a beloved snack all over the world, known for their distinct "sandwich" shape, dark chocolate cookies, and creamy filling. However, one of the most notable things about Oreos is the sheer variety of flavors that they come in. From classic flavors like vanilla and chocolate to more unique options like carrot cake and lemon, there seems to be an Oreo flavor for just about everyone. In this essay, we will explore the reasons behind the many flavors of Oreos and what they say about our changing tastes and desires as consumers. The origin of the name "Oreo" is unknown, but there are many hypotheses, including derivations from the French word or, meaning "gold", or from the Greek word ωραίο (oreo) meaning "nice" or "attractive". Others believe that the cookie was named Oreo simply because the name was short and easy to pronounce. First, it is important to understand the history of Oreo cookies. The original Oreo cookie was introduced in 1912 by the National Biscuit Company (now known as Nabisco), and it quickly became a popular snack in the United States. For instance, if you're someone who likes to eat an Oreo as is — no milk or twisting involved, you just bite straight in — chances are you're a cruncher. However, if you prefer to dunk an Oreo and let it soak in a glass of milk before you take a bite, you're most likely a part of the chewer category. However, it wasn't until 1975 that the first flavored Oreo was introduced: the golden Oreo, which featured a vanilla cookie and a vanilla cream filling. This was followed by other flavors like mint, peanut butter, and chocolate in the 1980s and 1990s. So why did Nabisco start introducing flavored Oreos in the first place? One reason is simply to appeal to consumers' desire for variety. As more and more snacks and treats became available on the market, companies like Nabisco realized that they needed to o ff er something di ff erent in order to stand out. By introducing new flavors of Oreos, Nabisco could capture the attention of consumers who might be bored with the same old cookie. Oreo cookies are distributed worldwide through a variety of sales and marketing channels. As their popularity continues to grow, so too does the amount of distribution that comes with it. According to the Kra � Foods company, the Oreo is the "World's Best Selling Cookie". In March 2012, Time magazine reported that Oreo cookies were available in more than 100 countries. Overall, it is estimated that since the Oreo cookie's inception in 1912, over 450 billion Oreos have been produced worldwide. Additionally, o ff ering a range of flavors allowed Nabisco to appeal to di ff erent tastes and preferences. For example, someone who didn't like chocolate might still enjoy a golden Oreo, while someone who loved peanut butter could try the peanut butter Oreo. Another reason for the proliferation of Oreo flavors is the rise of social media and the internet. In recent years, food blogging and social media platforms like Instagram have become increasingly popular, and companies like Nabisco have taken notice. Most of the Oreo production was once carried out at the Hershey's factory in Hershey,

Pennsylvania. "We're so excited to enter the metaverse! OREO 1 is the cookie that begs to be played with and we love to create new opportunities for our fans to connect with each other and share that playful spirit," Julia Rosenbloom, Oreo's Senior Brand Manager, said. By creating new and exciting Oreo flavors, Nabisco can generate buzz on social media and attract attention from food bloggers and influencers. By 2017, more than 40 billion Oreo cookies were being produced annually in 18 countries around the world.This, in turn, can help to boost sales and create a sense of excitement around the Oreo brand. The version produced in Canada (sold under the Christie's brand) included coconut oil but as of 2023, the ingredient list included vegetable oil and modified palm oil, similar to the American cookies. Of course, not all Oreo flavors are created equal. Some flavors, like chocolate and vanilla, are classic and beloved by consumers. Others, like watermelon and candy corn, have been less successful. So how does Nabisco decide which flavors to introduce and which to pass on? One factor is consumer research. Nabisco conducts extensive market research to determine which flavors are likely to be popular with consumers. It ʼ s safe to say many people eat Oreos the same way. They twist them apart, then consume the cookie as two separate creme-covered wafers. This might involve focus groups, surveys, and other types of market research to gather data on consumer preferences. Additionally, Nabisco pays attention to trends in the food industry and tries to stay ahead of the curve by introducing flavors that are likely to be popular in the future. For example, in recent years there has been a growing interest in plant-based foods, and Nabisco has responded by introducing a vegan-friendly version of the classic Oreo cookie. Another factor that influences the creation of new Oreo flavors is partnerships and collaborations. Nabisco has worked with a variety of other brands and companies to create new and unique flavors of Oreos.Yet more than a century a � er the Oreo ʼ s inception, many connoisseurs haven ʼ t solved a frustrating problem: how to twist it so both wafers end up with filling on them. For example, in 2021 Nabisco teamed up with the popular candy brand Sour Patch Kids to create a new flavor of Oreos featuring a sour cream filling. This type of collaboration allows Nabisco to tap into the popularity of another brand and create a buzz around the new flavor. Food scientists have spent years developing research-backed explanations for the world's undying love for Oreos. One 2016 study in the journal Chemical Senses showed that the cookie's classic combination of vanilla and chocolate is congruent, meaning that they come together in a way that satisfies our senses. However, nostalgia plays a big role too, says Popular Mechanics. Like Proust's madeleines, Oreos can transport you to a young, carefree time in your life, so however you ate Oreos as a child is likely the way you enjoy them today. Another 1993 study published in the National Library of Medicine suggests that the Oreo's creamy filling, sandwiched between two crispy chocolate cookies, creates something called "dynamic contrast" — a characteristic that all of the tastiest foods share. However, we all know that those

textures are completely dependent on the way you choose to eat your Oreo. In fact, the freedom of ritual Oreos allow is part of why they're so popular. 2 So what do the many flavors of Oreos say about our changing tastes as consumers? One trend that is clear is the growing interest in unique and unconventional flavors. Even Martha Stewart plans to join in on the fun. On Jan. 30, fans can tune into Oreo's Facebook or Instagram channels to watch the lifestyle expert navigate the Oreoverse herself. Stewart's close friend and gardener, Ryan McCallister, will tag along on the virtual adventure. In recent years, we have seen a rise in flavors like birthday cake, cinnamon bun, and even hot chicken wing, which might not have been considered mainstream flavors in the past. This trend is likely driven by a desire for novelty and excitement in our food choices, as well as a growing interest in global cuisine and diverse flavor profiles. Another trend reflected in the many flavors of Oreos is a focus on health and wellness. In recent years, there has been a growing interest in healthier snacking options, and Nabisco has responded by introducing flavors that cater to this trend. One six-pack of Oreos contains 270 calories, hence there are 45 calories in one cookie. Of these 45 calories, 27 come from carbohydrates, 16.5 come from fat, and 1.5 calories are provided by protein. For example, the thins version of Oreos o ff ers a lower calorie option, and the gluten-free and vegan options cater to consumers with dietary restrictions or preferences. Di ff erent Oreo flavors have varying amounts of carbohydrate: the chocolate fudge Oreo contains 13 g of total carbohydrates (4% of the recommended daily intake) and 9 g of sugars per serving of 3 cookies, while mint Oreos contain 25 g of total carbohydrates and 18 g of sugars per serving. Oreos contain small amounts of proteins and minerals (iron and sodium are present) but they do not contain any vitamins. Additionally, flavors like carrot cake and red velvet suggest a focus on "healthier" dessert options that include vegetables and fruits. Finally, the many flavors of Oreos speak to the power of branding and nostalgia. While some consumers may be drawn to the novelty of new flavors, many others have a deep emotional connection to the classic Oreo cookie. Available for presale now, the innovative flavor will hit shelves nationwide starting Jan. 30. By introducing new flavors, Nabisco is able to tap into this emotional connection while also expanding the brand's appeal to new consumers. Additionally, the limited edition and seasonal flavors of Oreos create a sense of urgency and scarcity that can make consumers feel like they are a part of something exclusive or special. In conclusion, the many flavors of Oreos are a reflection of our changing tastes as consumers, as well as the power of branding and marketing in the food industry. By o ff ering a wide range of flavors, Nabisco is able to cater to di ff erent tastes and preferences while also generating excitement and buzz around the Oreo brand. Whether you love classic flavors like chocolate and vanilla or prefer to try something new and exciting, there is an Oreo flavor for just about everyone. 3
